title: Integrated Change Control
description: Master the formal change control process—when CCB approval is needed and how to assess integrated impacts.
objectives: Distinguish CCB-required changes (baseline impacts) from PM-approved changes
Conduct integrated impact assessment across ALL baselines
Understand Change Control Board (CCB) roles and governance
Apply configuration management and baseline versioning
Recognize that CCB can modify change requests, not just approve/reject

screens.headline: Chef's Table Change Request: +$25K, +2 Weeks. Carlos Says 'Just Add It.' But Does It Need CCB Approval?

dialogue.text: Great idea! Just add it to the plan.

counterpoint.text: Not so fast. This affects multiple baselines—it needs formal change control through the CCB.

screens.learningHook: When does a change require formal CCB approval vs PM's direct approval?

screens.title: Change Control Governance
screens.instructions: Determine approval authority and assess integrated impacts.

scenarios.title: Stage 1: CCB vs PM Approval
description: Categorize which changes need CCB approval vs PM can approve directly.

items.label: Change meeting from Monday to Wednesday

feedback.correct: Perfect! CCB for baseline changes (1,3,5,7). PM for within-baseline changes (2,4,6,8).
feedback.incorrect: Ask: Does this change a baseline (scope, schedule, cost)? Yes = CCB. Within approved baseline = PM.

scenarios.title: Stage 2: Integrated Impact Assessment
description: Which baselines/plans are affected by the chef's table change?

feedback.correct: Excellent! One change affects 6 areas—that's why it's called INTEGRATED change control.
feedback.incorrect: Think across ALL knowledge areas: scope, schedule, cost, quality, risk, communications. Not just the originating area.

options.text: Approve with modifications: Reduce to 6 seats (saves 1 week, $18K), defer launch 3 weeks post-opening, weekly construction reviews
Defer decision until after grand opening

feedback.correct: Perfect! CCB can MODIFY—balance benefits with risk mitigation. Reduced scope + deferred launch protects opening while capturing marketing value.
feedback.incorrect: CCB doesn't just approve/reject. They can modify to optimize value while controlling risk.

content.definition: Process of reviewing all change requests, approving changes, and managing changes to baselines and documents.
keyPoints: Trigger: Change requests from ANY source
Scope: ALL baseline changes must go through this process
content.whyIntegrated: Assesses change impact across ALL knowledge areas, not just the originating area.

content.ccbVsPm: CCB approves baseline changes. PM approves within-baseline changes.

content.definition: Procedures to identify, document, and control changes to project deliverables.

example.v2.0: Major change approved by CCB (chef's table)

correct.text: We could have rejected (too risky) or approved as-is (2-week delay). But modifying (6 seats, deferred launch) gives us marketing value while protecting the opening. That's governance—not bureaucracy.

incorrect.text: CCB doesn't just say yes or no. They can modify to balance benefits and risks.

screens.title: Software Change Request
screens.context: Product Owner wants AI recommendation feature: +20 user stories, +6 weeks, +$80K, 75% initial accuracy (target 90%).

options.text: Modify: Defer AI to v2.0, release v1.0 on schedule, use v1.0 data to train AI to 90%+
Defer AI to v2.0, release v1.0 on time
Develop AI in parallel for Jan v2.0
Use v1.0 data to train AI to 90%+

screens.title: Change Control Mastery
screens.summary: Integrated Change Control ensures all baseline changes go through formal governance. CCB can approve, modify, reject, or defer.
takeaways: Assess impact across ALL knowledge areas
CCB can MODIFY requests (not just yes/no)
7-step process: Request → Review → Assess → Recommend → Decide → Update → Communicate

characterClosing.text: I wanted to approve chef's table immediately because I liked the idea. But Alex's impact assessment showed the risks. CCB modified the request to balance benefits and risks. Now I understand why baseline changes need governance.
